articles.headline: Placing the Blame as Students Are Buried in Debt
articles.snippet: Is it really worth $100,000 in debt to graduate from a top school? And is it responsible?
articles.abstract: Is it really worth $100,000 in debt to graduate from a top school? And is it responsible?
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many middle-class families, Cortney Munna and her mother began the college selection process with a grim determination. They would do whatever they could to get Cortney into the best possible college, and they maintained a blind faith that the investment would be worth it.

articles.headline: When Afghans Seek Medical Aid, Tough Choice for U.S.
articles.snippet: Civilians wounded as a result of military activity are treated by the military. But each day, Afghans seek help for other ailments.
articles.abstract: Civilians wounded as a result of military activity are treated by the military. But each day, Afghans seek help for other ailments.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAN NESHIN, Afghanistan  Five-year-old Sadiq was not a casualty of war. He was simply unlucky. The boy had opened a sack of grain at his home early on Wednesday morning, and a pit viper coiled inside lashed up and bit him above the lip.

articles.headline: As ‘Don’t Ask’ Fades, Military Faces Thorny Issues
articles.snippet: The possible repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy presents the Pentagon with a new challenge: how to transition to a force where homosexuals serve openly.
articles.abstract: The possible repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy presents the Pentagon with a new challenge: how to transition to a force where homosexuals serve openly.
articles.lead_paragraph: For opponents of the ban against homosexuals serving openly in the military, the steps by Congress this week to repeal the policy, known as “don’t ask, don’t tell,” were a major victory. But now they are girding for what may be an equally difficult task: the transition to a force where straight and openly gay servicemen and women live, work and fight alongside one other.

articles.headline: Owners Bet on Raising the Rent, and Lost
articles.snippet: Owners of apartment complexes in New York  and San Francisco failed to replace rent-regulated residents with higher-paying tenants and fell into financial straits.
articles.abstract: Owners of apartment complexes in New York  and San Francisco failed to replace rent-regulated residents with higher-paying tenants and fell into financial straits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first signs of financial turmoil came at Riverton Houses in Harlem.

articles.headline: House Votes to Eliminate Hedge Fund Tax Break
articles.snippet: “Carried interest,” the portion of a fund’s investment gains taken by fund managers, is taxed at 15 percent as a capital gain; the legislation would raise that rate.
articles.abstract: “Carried interest,” the portion of a fund’s investment gains taken by fund managers, is taxed at 15 percent as a capital gain; the legislation would raise that rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The House passed a bill on Friday that would end a tax break for executives of investment funds, leaving hedge funds, private equity firms and venture capitalists scrambling to ease the effects of the bill before it is taken up by the Senate next month.

articles.headline: The Politicking Behind an Offer to a Specter Foe
articles.snippet: A talk with Joe Sestak has become a dispute over whether the usual is enough for a president promising reform.
articles.abstract: A talk with Joe Sestak has become a dispute over whether the usual is enough for a president promising reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House lavished attention on Senator Arlen Specter when he switched parties last year, but Rahm Emanuel realized he had a problem. To secure the seat for the Republican-turned-Democrat, Mr. Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, wanted to clear the path for Mr. Specter to win his new party’s nomination.

articles.headline: Documents Show Early Worries About Safety of Rig
articles.snippet: Internal documents show that BP had concerns with the oil rig earlier than was described in its findings presented to Congress.
articles.abstract: Internal documents show that BP had concerns with the oil rig earlier than was described in its findings presented to Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Internal documents from BP show that there were serious problems and safety concerns with the Deepwater Horizon rig far earlier than those the company described to Congress last week.

articles.headline: In Camouflage or Veil, a Fragile Bond
articles.snippet: Female Marines in Helmand Province have the daunting mission of winning over the Afghan women who are culturally off limits to American men.
articles.abstract: Female Marines in Helmand Province have the daunting mission of winning over the Afghan women who are culturally off limits to American men.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABDUL GHAYAS, Afghanistan — Two young female Marines trudged along with an infantry patrol in the 102-degree heat, soaked through their camouflage uniforms under 60 pounds of gear. But only when they reached this speck of a village in the Taliban heartland on a recent afternoon did their hard work begin.

articles.headline: BP Prepares to Take New Tack on Leak After ‘Top Kill’ Fails
articles.snippet: BP engineers said that their latest attempt to stop the oil leak had been unsuccessful, and, after consultation with government officials, they had decided to move on to another strategy.
articles.abstract: BP engineers said that their latest attempt to stop the oil leak had been unsuccessful, and, after consultation with government officials, they had decided to move on to another strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  In another serious setback in the effort to stem the flow of oil gushing from a well a mile beneath the Gulf of Mexico, BP engineers said Saturday that the “top kill” technique had failed and, after consultation with government officials, they had decided to move on to another strategy.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Barry Sternlicht, the Real Estate Bargain Hunter
articles.snippet: When real estate crashed, Barry Sternlicht, creator of Starwood Hotels, bought condo buildings from Las Vegas to Miami. Now he waits for tenants.
articles.abstract: When real estate crashed, Barry Sternlicht, creator of Starwood Hotels, bought condo buildings from Las Vegas to Miami. Now he waits for tenants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Miami

articles.headline: 3,000 Pages of Financial Reform, but Still Not Enough
articles.snippet: Flaws in both financial reform bills would allow Wall Street to continue trading derivatives with little transparency.
articles.abstract: Flaws in both financial reform bills would allow Wall Street to continue trading derivatives with little transparency.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, until Congress did away with it 11 years ago, a Depression-era law known as Glass-Steagall ably protected bank customers, individual investors and the financial system as a whole from the kind of outright destruction we’ve witnessed over the last few years.

articles.headline: The Doctor Will See You Now. Please Log On.
articles.snippet: Advances in video technology and a need to reduce medical costs have made interactive telemedicine a growing business.
articles.abstract: Advances in video technology and a need to reduce medical costs have made interactive telemedicine a growing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE day last summer, Charlie Martin felt a sharp pain in his lower back. But he couldn’t jump into his car and rush to the doctor’s office or the emergency room: Mr. Martin, a crane operator, was working on an oil rig in the South China Sea off Malaysia.

articles.headline: In Ohio, Gauge for Midterms, Economy Rules
articles.snippet: A governor’s race will speak to a big question: Will voters see enough improvement to grant Democrats more time?
articles.abstract: A governor’s race will speak to a big question: Will voters see enough improvement to grant Democrats more time?
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ALBANY, Ohio  Good economic news has been virtually extinct in Ohio for a few years now, but Gov. Ted Strickland suddenly finds himself overseeing small yet hopeful moments of recovery: ribbon-cutting ceremonies, groundbreaking events for business parks and televised announcements that jobs are slowly returning to the state.

articles.headline: White House Tries to Regroup as Criticism Mounts Over Leak
articles.snippet: Officials acknowledged the possibility that tens of thousands of barrels of oil might continue pouring into the gulf until August.
articles.abstract: Officials acknowledged the possibility that tens of thousands of barrels of oil might continue pouring into the gulf until August.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Clifford Krauss, John M. Broder and Jackie Calmes.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss, John M. Broder and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Sam’s Club Personalizes Discounts for Buyers
articles.snippet: A new program from the warehouse chain offers different bargains to each member, based on their buying history.
articles.abstract: A new program from the warehouse chain offers different bargains to each member, based on their buying history.
articles.lead_paragraph: SECAUCUS, N.J.  For years, hotels, airlines, banks, online retailers and other data-driven businesses have turned to powerful computers to help determine the optimal price for their products, or to find ways to recommend items that groups of customers with similar tastes might want to buy.

articles.headline: Town & Country Magazine Tries to Broaden Readership
articles.snippet: The magazine once covered a clearly defined world of high society, but today that can seem largely irrelevant. The new editor hopes to broaden its coverage and readership.
articles.abstract: The magazine once covered a clearly defined world of high society, but today that can seem largely irrelevant. The new editor hopes to broaden its coverage and readership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Promoting $29,000 diamond and rubellite cuffs and $30,000 Louis XVI guéridons (a very expensive sort of side table), Town & Country magazine may seem to have gavotted through the recession.

articles.headline: Tech Innovator in Japan Sets Its Sights on China
articles.snippet: Softbank’s most promising ventures are in China, where it has made a series of strategic investments in an array of prominent Net companies.
articles.abstract: Softbank’s most promising ventures are in China, where it has made a series of strategic investments in an array of prominent Net companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  A Japanese technology giant little known outside Asia is racing to capture the booming Chinese Internet market. And in the process, it hopes to become a global player straddling what is fast becoming the world’s most wired region.

articles.headline: A Cultural Artifact, on the Block
articles.snippet: In a publishing landscape filled with the infirm, weeklies are the most profoundly challenged, but three classes of long-shot buyers might consider Newsweek as bids come due for the magazine.
articles.abstract: In a publishing landscape filled with the infirm, weeklies are the most profoundly challenged, but three classes of long-shot buyers might consider Newsweek as bids come due for the magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: This Wednesday at close of business, the first nonbinding letters of interest are due for Newsweek.

articles.headline: U.S. to Aid South Korea With Naval Defense Plan
articles.snippet: The sinking of a warship revealed that South Korea is still vulnerable to a surprise attack, U.S. officials say.
articles.abstract: The sinking of a warship revealed that South Korea is still vulnerable to a surprise attack, U.S. officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Surprised by how easily a South Korean warship was sunk by what an international investigation concluded was a North Korean torpedo fired from a midget submarine, senior American officials say they are planning a long-term program to plug major gaps in the South’s naval defenses.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: An Untapped Phone Call in Italy? It’s Possible
articles.snippet: In Italy, you’re nobody if your phone isn’t tapped. But to rein in leaks, a contentious new law would restrict the ability to wiretap and publish the results.
articles.abstract: In Italy, you’re nobody if your phone isn’t tapped. But to rein in leaks, a contentious new law would restrict the ability to wiretap and publish the results.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  In Italy, you’re nobody if your phone isn’t tapped. Or, as Beppe Grillo, Italy’s leading political provocateur and blogger, put it: “This is a nation where if you can’t be blackmailed, you’ll never get ahead.”

articles.headline: Blacks in Memphis Lose Decades of Economic Gains
articles.snippet: Foreclosures and unemployment have destroyed black wealth and income and erased two decades of slow progress.
articles.abstract: Foreclosures and unemployment have destroyed black wealth and income and erased two decades of slow progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — For two decades, Tyrone Banks was one of many African-Americans who saw his economic prospects brightening in this Mississippi River city.

articles.headline: Web Start-Ups Offer Bargains for Users’ Data
articles.snippet: Start-ups are pushing to see how much data consumers are willing to give up in exchange for getting a deal.
articles.abstract: Start-ups are pushing to see how much data consumers are willing to give up in exchange for getting a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: As concern increases in Washington about the amount of private data online, and as big sites like Facebook draw criticism that they collect consumers’ information in a stealthy manner, many Web start-ups are pursuing a more reciprocal approach  saying, in essence: give us your data and get something in return.

articles.headline: Fears Rise in Europe Over Potential for Deflation
articles.snippet: Economists are beginning to worry that deflation is a bigger threat than inflation in Europe.
articles.abstract: Economists are beginning to worry that deflation is a bigger threat than inflation in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  If the European Central Bank has one monetary dragon it considers essential to slay, it is inflation.

articles.headline: Deadly Israeli Raid Draws Condemnation
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel canceled his plans for meeting with President Obama after a raid on ships carrying supplies for Gaza left nine people dead.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel canceled his plans for meeting with President Obama after a raid on ships carrying supplies for Gaza left nine people dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel faced intense international condemnation and growing domestic questions on Monday after a raid by naval commandos that killed nine people, many of them Turks, on an aid flotilla bound for Gaza.

articles.headline: Venting Online, Consumers Can Find Themselves in Court
articles.snippet: Lawyers say that a growing number of businesses are suing individuals for posting critical comments online.
articles.abstract: Lawyers say that a growing number of businesses are suing individuals for posting critical comments online.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a towing company hauled Justin Kurtz’s car from his apartment complex parking lot, despite his permit to park there, Mr. Kurtz, 21, a college student in Kalamazoo, Mich., went to the Internet for revenge.
